content: The Act may be cited as the "Best Return on America's Investment Now Act" or the "BRAIN Act." It includes provisions for immigrant visas for certain advanced STEM graduates. The "Best Return on America's Investment Now Act" or the "BRAIN Act" includes provisions for immigrant visas for advanced STEM graduates holding doctorate degrees from U.S. institutions in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The "BRAIN Act" allows immigrant visas for STEM doctoral graduates who completed all courses in the U.S. in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The "BRAIN Act" allows immigrant visas for STEM doctoral graduates who completed all courses in the U.S. in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. Education's Classification of Instructional Programs taxonomy includes computer and information sciences, engineering, mathematics, and physical sciences. The term 'United States doctoral institution of higher education' is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Carnegie Foundation or National Science Foundation classified the institution as a doctorate-granting university with high research activity. The institution was classified as a doctorate-granting university with high research activity. Amendments were made to the procedure for granting immigrant status under the Act, including changes to processing standards for petitions related to alien beneficiaries. The Secretary shall adjudicate petitions within 60 days of filing, with a 30-day extension if additional information is requested. If the petition does not meet standards, the petitioner will be notified within 30 days of filing. The Secretary must promptly review and allow resubmission of modified petitions. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding skilled workers and professionals are specified. A study on the National Science Foundation's use of classification authority is required by June 30, 2018. The effective date for these amendments is October 1, 2014, applying to fiscal years thereafter. The Secretary of Homeland Security can accept petitions before a specified date for alien beneficiaries qualifying under a new section of the Immigration and Nationality Act. SEC. 3. Numerical limitation to any single foreign state. Section 202(a)(2) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include subsection (a), and paragraphs (3), (4), and (5) of subsection (b). Section 202(a)(5) is also amended for Rules for Employment-Based Immigrants. Section 202(e) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include subsection (a), and paragraphs (3), (4), and (5) of subsection (b). The amendments made by this section will be effective on October 1, 2014, applying to fiscal years starting on or after that date. SEC. 4. PERMANENT PRIORITY DATES. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to establish permanent priority dates for employment-based petitions. The priority date will be the date of filing with the Secretary of Homeland Security, unless a labor certification was filed first. Beneficiaries of approvable employment-based petitions will retain their priority date. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to establish permanent priority dates for employment-based petitions. Beneficiaries will retain the priority date assigned to their petition for future filings. The amendment will be effective on October 1, 2014, applying to aliens with pending classification petitions on or after that date.
